MSE Library hours may be cut
By ELLEN BERNHARD
Campus-wide energy cuts
made in response to rising fuel
costs may include a 25-hour per
week reduction in the operating
hours of the MSE Library, according to Head Librarian David
Stam and Steve Lovejoy, undergraduate representatiNte to the Library Advisory Committee.
If the cut is enforced, the Library,.now open daily from 8:00
a.m. to midnight, will probably
adopt the following operating
schedule: 8:30 a.m. to 11:00
p.m. Monday through Thursday,
8:30 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. Friday
and Saturday, and 1:00 p.m. to
11:00 p.m. Sunday.
Stam revealed that he was contacted a month ago by Homewood Vice President George
Benton and told to review the
Library's operating schedule "to
see what reductions would affect
the least number of people."
He said he is displeased with
the tentative reduced. schedule,
asserting that he "does not want
to cut hours at all."
Lovejoy said that the Student
Council, the Library Advisory
Committee, and numerous fac-

ulty members have protested the
cut. "I feel that the Library
should be cut last," he said. "After all, it is the central area of
campus activity, and the reserves
are located there."
Lovejoy said that though he
realizes the Library must be subject to some curtailment of services as part of campus-wide fuel
conservation measures, he considers the 25 hour cut "excessive."
In response to suggestions that
the operating hours of specified
areas of the Library rather than
the entire facility be reduced,
Stam said that the "vertical zone
heating system" which heats the
building would make such an approach infeasible.
"Let's face it," he said. "This
building was not designed for
conservation of energy."
"As it's set up now, the air
conditioner often comes on to
b ring the heat down to the
thermostatic level," he said.
"That's a pure waste of energy."
Stam stated that he is concerned with the delicate volumes
and manuscripts, now housed in
temperature-controlled areas,

which could be endangered by
fuel cuts.
"I am also concerned for the
130 people on my staff," he continued. "If morning hours are cut
and they have to come to work
later, there would also certainly
be a monumental parking problem"
He asserted that the proposed
reduction in hours would not
yield "substantial savings" in
staff salaries.

Debuskey named chairman of pre-med committee
By LAINY STEPHANS
Dr. Matthew Debuskey, advisor for "the growing influx of
pre-med students" has been
named Chairman of the Pre-Med
Recommendation Committee.
Debuskey, who replaced Dr.
Martin Larrabee as head of the
committee that compiles reviews
for medical school applicants has
noted a trend toward higher entrance qualifications.
"Three years ago, the mean
score for students entering med
school was about 3.2. Now, a
cumultive GPA of 3.5 is minimumi for just about every
school," he stated.
Debuskey commented that he
thought the higher statistics are
the result, of a rapid increase in
the number of medical school applicants.
"I just finished meeting with
directors from 18 medical
schools, to see if there was some
uniform standard. They were all
concerned with the increase to
45,000 students applying for
15,000' places. That's a one in
three chance of acceptance," he
commented.
The new chairman revealed
that five years ago 30,000 students were applying for the same
number of openings—a one in two
chance of acceptance.
In view of this competition,
Debuskey said that the purpose

of the committee is to provide
additional information to admissions offices besides the numerical score from the GPA and the
MCATs.
"Other traits are important in
medicine. Our committee extracts facts from solicited letters
and reports to form the basis of a
review on the virtues of the applicants," the chairman explained.
He added that the objective of
the 20-member committee is to

stress an applicant's strong points
and to explain posssible falterings
in numerical scores.
However, Debuskey expressed
concern that the recent federal
law, proposed by Senator
Buckley, allowing students to see
their school files, will diminish
the effect of these recommendations.
"If we send recommendation s
saying everyone's! is a real 'jewel'
and they prove to be just 'paste',

then eventually admissions offices will just ignore them and
rely even more on numerical
scores," he asserted.
Debuskey revealed, however,
that this situation may be
remedied by a proposed amendment to the bill, which alIbws a
school to ask a student fpr a
waiver stating that he will not request his files.
"This waiver, if implemented,
will also not allow students to see

their files at schools, at the time
they are applying," he noted.
"Only after they have enrolled,
when it doesn't really matter,
will students be allowed tc see
their files."
"I hope to be accessible anytime and to review the records of
pre-med students after their third
semester. I want to pick out the
people whose opportunity seems
diminished by their grade average," he stated.

The tentative 25-hour per week cut in the operating hours
of the MSE Library must be regarded as another sin of
insensitivity towards the needs of a university community.
We agree with Steve Lovejoy, undergraduate representative to
the Library Advisory Committee, that the proposed cut is
"excessive" and that the Library should be the last area to
suffer such measures.
The administration has previously exhibited a lack of
concern for the fate of volumes stored in the antiquated
Gilman Hall stacks, delaying again and again the allocation of
funds needed to renovate that overflow storage area.
Likewise, the acquisition budget for the Library has remained
at a relatively low level, far off-register with other university
libraries of comparable quality.
The proposed cut in hours—in line with this trend—is
remarkable for the sheer magnitude of inconvenience it will
bring about, not only for undergraduates, but for graduate
students who need the research materials, and for faculty
members who have relied on the accessibility of the facility
for so long. The early Saturday closing time along with the
late Sunday opening time will •effectively preclude the
prolonged access to reserve materials that is so necessary for
grad students who are researching dissertations, or undergrads
who are writing or researching papers. Just as serious, the
Library will cease to be a reliable and accessible study
area—independent of its resources—for students who
frequently have no other refuge.
We urge that the implications of the proposed cut be
reconsidered by the appropriate officials before such a
Draconian measure is enforced.,

The tentative 25-hour per week cut in the operating hours
of the MSE Library must be regarded as another sin of
insensitivity towards the needs of a university community.
We agree with Steve Lovejoy, undergraduate representative to
the Library Advisory Committee, that the proposed cut is
"excessive" and that the Library should be the last area to
suffer such measures.
The administration has previously exhibited a lack of
concern for the fate of volumes stored in the antiquated
Gilman Hall stacks, delaying again and again the allocation of
funds needed to renovate that overflow storage area.
Likewise, the acquisition budget for the Library has remained
at a relatively low level, far off-register with other university
libraries of comparable quality.
The proposed cut in hours—in line with this trend—is
remarkable for the sheer magnitude of inconvenience it will
bring about, not only for undergraduates, but for graduate
students who need the research materials, and for faculty
members who have relied on the accessibility of the facility
for so long. The early Saturday closing time along with the
late Sunday opening time will •effectively preclude the
prolonged access to reserve materials that is so necessary for
grad students who are researching dissertations, or undergrads
who are writing or researching papers. Just as serious, the
Library will cease to be a reliable and accessible study
area—independent of its resources—for students who
frequently have no other refuge.
We urge that the implications of the proposed cut be
reconsidered by the appropriate officials before such a
Draconian measure is enforced.,

Blue Jay grappler Steve
Lazzaro has been chosen as Hopkins' first Athlete of the Week.
Though the wrestling team dropped both of its meets this past
week, to American University
and Towson State, Lazzaro won

both of his matches, 7-2 against
American and 12-2 (superior decision) at Towson. Those two
wins lifted his season record to
9-0, making him the only unbeateri,, untied Homewood wrestler.

Baltimore. He attended Overlea

senior he compiled a 24-1-1 record capturing the Maryland

Lazzaro had a 10-2 dual meet record wrestling at 118. He finished second in the MAC's losing
out to the eventual Division III
iational champion.

Gotwals said of Lazzaro, "He's
matured and improved greatly

very determined and one of the
hardest workers on the team. He
is definitely the most active student of wrestling on the squad."
